news.title: The moment Trump caused his own undoing
news.text:
Within weeks of becoming president, Donald Trump found there was a sticky piece of gum on his shoe involving the late Jeffrey Epstein that he couldnâ€™t scrape off. This was surprising, because Trump had survived sex scandals involving a porn star, a libel suit over alleged sexual abuse, a tape of crude â€œlocker roomâ€ talk about groping womenâ€™s genitals, and more.

Trump thought he could cry â€œhoax!â€ about his friendship with the billionaire paedophile and his Maga base would meekly fall silent. Some did. Others dismissed the furore as â€œMe Tooâ€ hysteria, or are pointing the finger at liberals like Bill Clinton who were in the sex offenderâ€™s orbit. But ask Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor whether the Epstein scandal ever truly goes away.

Trumpâ€™s election-winning shtick was that his â€œwokeâ€ opponent Kamala Harris was for â€œthey/themâ€ (such as immigrants and transgender people), while â€œTrump is for Youâ€. This is the year he revealed himself to be for â€œhe/himâ€ and for â€œthey/themâ€, not us, enriching himself, his family and the billionaire tech and finance bros.

If there is a date when the rot set into the Trump presidency, it was when attorney general Pam Bondi announced on 21 February that a list of Epsteinâ€™s clients was â€œsitting on my deskâ€. A week later she infuriated the Magaverseâ€™s slavering conspiracy theorists, who were certain there was an establishment cover-up, by releasing binders of recycled old news. 

This broke the bond of trust between Trump and his supporters, who felt played for fools. It led Republican firebrand Marjorie Taylor-Greene to crash furiously out of his fanzone and announce she was quitting Congress in the new year. But most of all, it made Trump look like the sleazy swamp creature he had always railed against.

And if anyone persisted in raising questions about Epstein, he tried to shut them up, such as by responding â€œQuiet, piggyâ€ to a female Bloomberg News reporter on board Air Force One. It didnâ€™t work.

On Friday, the Justice department released an enormous batch of documents under the Epstein Files Transparency Act, which was meant to include â€œall unclassified records, documents, communications, and investigative materialsâ€ held by the department and FBI. 

This was only reluctantly signed into law by Trump after months of pressure and his administration is continuing to slow-walk the process. In retrospect, it was all too foreseeable that Trumpâ€™s legal strategy would be to deploy the â€œthree Dâ€™sâ€: delay, deny and denigrate.

There are reams of blacked-out, redacted pages in the Justice departmentâ€™s partial document dump, supposedly to protect national security and Epsteinâ€™s sex abuse victims, even though they have been clamouring for the full release of the files. 

In the new trove are two phone messages for Epstein from a redacted caller bluntly stating: â€œI have a Female for him.â€ Intriguingly, Ghislaine Maxwell is revealed to have alleged in a habeas corpus petition that Epsteinâ€™s lawyers reached â€œsecret settlementsâ€ with 25 men. Who are they? Will we ever know?

Additionally, there is a fuzzy image of Trump with an array of women. But weâ€™ve seen plenty of these in the Epstein files previously made public by the House Oversight Committee.

Indeed there are so many photographs of Trump and other bigwigs with Epstein (including the pop star Michael Jackson) in the public domain that the phrase by Steve Bannon, Trumpâ€™s former strategist, about â€œflooding the zone with shitâ€ comes to mind.

There has been almost too much stuff to process from documents released in recent months, from novelty condoms with a caricature of Trumpâ€™s face and the text, â€œIâ€™m HUUUUGEâ€, to Epsteinâ€™s 50th birthday book with a creepy letter and squiggly portrait of a naked young woman allegedly bearing Trumpâ€™s signature in place of her pubic hair (Trump is suing the Wall Street Journal for claiming he wrote it).

And, by the way, Bannon himself â€“ the seedy Mr America First and flamethrowing podcaster â€“ appears in the files, shamelessly offering PR advice and sharing a mirror selfie with Epstein.

If the US economy were roaring all might be forgiven. But Trump has reportedly busied himself with accumulating up to an estimated $1.8bn for himself and his family via his businesses while Americans are facing an affordability crisis.

This, too, according to Trump, is a â€œhoaxâ€, but the Epstein saga has weakened his credibility on this score. The President has graded himself A+ on the economy, when voters are scared about jobs, housing and inflation in 2026.

Grasping for legacy, Trump has been prematurely celebrating peace agreements, pressing regime change in Venezuela, naming buildings after himself â€“ the Trump Institute of Peace and now the cultural Trump-Kennedy Center â€“ and desecrating the White House with a vulgar $400m ballroom and an offensive, trolling Presidential â€œwalk of fameâ€.

Ever the master of distraction, Trump went on television on Wednesday to boast about his alleged present and future triumphs. He promised the voters large tax refunds this spring and offered US troops cash handouts of $1,776 in honour of the 250th anniversary of American independence.

Trump also dangled the prospect of cash handouts of up to $2,000 to all tax-payers, similar to the Covid relief payments in his first term. Economists warn this could unleash more price rises but the President was buoyed by inflation coming in lower than expected at 2.7 per cent for November.

With a new, Maga-friendly chairman of the Federal Reserve set to arrive in May, one thing is certain: the 2026 economy will be all Trumpâ€™s, not Joe Bidenâ€™s. He has to hope the chips fall his way, because persistent questions about Epstein will remain.

We still donâ€™t know the mysterious origins of the sex offenderâ€™s purported billions, though we do know a slew of rich, powerful and/or influential men, including left-wing guru Noam Chomsky and liberal filmmaker Woody Allen were happy to share his company.

As for Trump, his name appears at least 1,500 times in the files, although he is lucky to have broken off his friendship with Epstein before the paedophile was convicted of soliciting underage sex in 2008. Epstein himself claimed in a letter to Maxwell, his partner-in-crime, that Trump was â€œthat dog that hasnâ€™t barkedâ€ and that a named sex trafficking victim spent â€œhours at my house with himâ€.

Maxwell, who is now housed in a cushy, open prison in Texas after a sweetheart deal with the Trump administration, replied to Epstein, â€œI have been thinking about that.â€

Some things, once seen, canâ€™t be unseen, and once thought, canâ€™t be unthought. There is no evidence to suggest Trump committed a crime, but Epstein will be a lasting stain on his legacy.

Call it rough justice, but guilt by association is a Trumpian speciality.

Sarah Baxter is director of the Marie Colvin Center for International Reporting
news.author: Sarah Baxter

news.title: Labour faces 'extinction level' threat as support fragments to Reform and Greens
news.text:
Westminster limped to the festive finish line this week with MPs and ministers exhausted by another chaotic year in British politics, which is yet again ending with a prime minister fighting for their political future.

Labour has endured a disastrous year, going from neck-and-neck with Reform UK â€“ and well ahead of the Conservatives â€“ in the polls, to 10 points behind the right-wing insurgents and in danger of slipping to fourth place thanks to a modest Tory recovery and the rise of the Greens.

Many of those around Sir Keir Starmer recognise the depths of the Governmentâ€™s plight â€“ although they point out that Britain is not alone in seeing a populist surge, with the failure in the US of Joe Biden and Kamala Harris to hold on to support for the Democratic Party a key warning sign.

â€œLeft-wing parties around the world have lost touch with the working classes and so working-class people feel neglected,â€ one No 10 insider told The i Paper. â€œJust look at the Democrats â€“ though weâ€™re not as bad as that!â€

The bar for success on a day-to-day level has been set low. A Government source said that the Budget in November was seen as a success â€œbecause no one was forced to resign over itâ€.

â€˜We need to tell people about the good thingsâ€™

The key, according to Starmer and many others in Labour, is to improve the communications. â€œWe canâ€™t just say that weâ€™re fixing problems, we need to tell people about the good things we are doing in their lives,â€ one Government adviser said. â€œAnd there is quite a lot of it but voters donâ€™t know about it.â€

The Prime Minister told the Cabinet immediately after the Budget that ministers should now focus their efforts on promoting initiatives such as freezes to bus fares, train tickets and prescription charges; the removal of Â£150 worth of levies from energy bills; and the rollout of free breakfast clubs in schools. 

Meanwhile, his right-hand man, chief of staff Morgan McSweeney, told a meeting of special advisers to take inspiration from Australia, whose centre-left leader Anthony Albanese won re-election through concentrating on the cost of living.

Starmer is now considering making a speech on the issue early next month.

An MP said: â€œWe all have a role to play. If you canâ€™t sell that weâ€™re lifting half a million children out of poverty, that weâ€™re increasing the minimum wage, that weâ€™re helping parents with the cost of school uniforms and giving free breakfasts then thatâ€™s on you.â€

A different backbencher agreed that living costs were â€œwhat my constituents care most aboutâ€ and called on ministers to be â€œmuch clearer about what weâ€™re doing, why weâ€™re doing itâ€.

They said that it had never been more challenging to be in Government, pointing for example to a profusion of anti-Labour channels on YouTube, many of which spread fake news. â€œThat means we have to be even better to counterbalance that environment,â€ the MP added.

But at the same time as trying to communicate more with the public â€“ including by launching his own TikTok account and a Substack newsletter â€“ Starmer this week moved to shut down transparency by cutting the number of weekly media briefings offered by No 10 from eight to five. 

The scrapped briefings would be replaced by â€œoccasionalâ€ press conferences with ministers at which online influencers and a small number of hand-picked journalists will be able to ask questions, Downing Street comms chief Tim Allan said.

The gambit has appalled some Labour veterans who believe the party must take every opportunity to spread its message. 

One source said: â€œWhen the country isnâ€™t listening and the papers arenâ€™t convinced, the answer isnâ€™t turn off one of the mics. Itâ€™s grab every single one, crank up the volume, make your argument.â€

Big test comes in May

The big test of Starmerâ€™s leadership, and whether his policies really are starting to shift the dial as allies hope, will come in May at elections for the Scottish and Welsh Parliaments, as well as local councils across much of England.

Reform UK strategists are expecting big gains in the most pro-Brexit areas of the country. A party source joked: â€œSometimes I just lie in bed thinking about how great the local election areas are for us. Sunderland, Dudley â€“ itâ€™s perfect. Everywhere except the shires!â€

And Wales has become apparently a two-horse race between Reform and Plaid Cymru, ending a century of Labour domination there. 

A poll this week showed Starmerâ€™s party on just 10 per cent â€“ which for one MP is more evidence that the leader must go.

â€œThis is extinction level stuff,â€ they said. â€œI personally canâ€™t see a scenario where he takes us into the next election. I even wonder whether he might just decide to do what is right himself and step down to allow for someone else to come in.â€

Another Labour MP dismissed claims that removing Starmer would be disloyal to the man who engineered last yearâ€™s general election victory, insisting: â€œItâ€™s precisely because I know how bad a Reform government would be for my constituents that I will do whatever is needed to stop that happening and keep Labour in power.â€

The problem for the Prime Ministerâ€™s critics is that there is still no obvious replacement. Andy Burnham is outside Parliament, Angela Rayner â€“ who is currently writing a memoir and is widely tipped for a return to the Cabinet in 2026 â€“ risks still being tarred by the controversy over her taxes, and Wes Streeting may prove too right-wing for Labour activists to accept. 

â€œYou just have to keep plodding on,â€ one MP said.

Another Labour source said: â€œI donâ€™t believe that there will be a leadership move after the May elections, that is the narrative every year and it pretty much never happens. 

â€œThe truth is they donâ€™t have a viable candidate who actually gets better numbers than Starmer, so they donâ€™t have any momentum. I suspect that after a couple of weeks the local election results are forgotten and nothing has happened.â€ 

And a Government insider predicted that MPs would â€œget scaredâ€ by the prospect of party members choosing a new leader well to the left of Starmer.

Tories showing signs of recovery

Meanwhile, the Conservatives appear convinced that their recovery is in full swing, after a marked improvement in Kemi Badenochâ€™s performance at weekly bouts of Prime Ministerâ€™s Questions. 

Speaking to the 1922 Committee of backbenchers on Wednesday, the leader said: â€œNext year wonâ€™t be easy. We lost the trust of the public. But we can turn it aroundâ€¦ and we will do it in one term.â€ A member of her shadow Cabinet joked: â€œWe got dumped by the electorate because weâ€™d let ourselves go. We need a glow-up!â€

The Liberal Democrats, too, are generally optimistic. Their rating in nationwide opinion polls has plateaued this year, but they have made key gains in council by-elections. 

Some mutterings are beginning to start among MPs who fear that voters do not know what Sir Ed Davey stands for, however â€“ one said: â€œWe need to have a stronger brand, a stronger message. But thereâ€™s still time for that.â€

And the Greens, along with Reform, have been the big success story of the year under their energetic new leader Zack Polanski. 

They have been squeezing Labour from the left, although Starmerâ€™s team remain confident of dealing with them in time for the next general election.

â€œThe Greens will get a lot more scrutiny as we get closer to an election and people will start to understand what their policies are,â€ a senior Government source said. 

â€œWill 20 per cent of people really vote for those policies?â€

They insisted that â€œthere is only room for two partiesâ€, adding that Starmer will copy the strategy of Emmanuel Macron who won two elections by saying â€œyou have to vote for me to keep out the far rightâ€ â€“ an argument you can expect to hear more and more loudly from Labour throughout 2026.
